p: Mutoko is a district of Mashonaland East Province, Zimbabwe, in southern Africa (see Figure 1). It is located in the eastern part of Zimbabwe, and covers 4092.5 km 2 (Mvumi, Donaldson & Mhunduru 1988). According to the 2012 population census, Mutoko has 146 127 inhabitants (Moyo 2016). It was established as an administrative station in 1911 and it lies 143 km from Harare, the capital city of Zimbabwe. The area is occupied by the Buja people. The Buja people are said to have settled in Mutoko from Mhingari in what is now Mozambique. The subsistence economy of Mutoko rural community is based on conservation farming (Fanelli & Dumba 2011). The most favourable crops in the area include maize, groundnuts, vegetables, sunflowers, sorghum, cotton, pearl millet and finger millet (Mvumi et al. 1998). The climate in the area is mild, and generally warm and temperate (Fanelli & Dumba 2011). Mutoko rural district is divided into 29 wards, each consisting of six villages, with about 1000 people per village or 80â€“120 families (Mvumi et al. 1998).
